analytic.title: Fish and Shellfish Immunology

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Gibel carp Fermented Moringa oleifera Lam. leaves Growth Immune responses Antioxidant

abstract.p: Full length article Effects of dietary fish meal replacement by fermented moringa (Moringa oleifera Lam.) leaves on growth performance, nonspecific immunity and disease resistance against Aeromonas hydrophila in juvenile gibel carp (Carassius auratus gibelio var. CAS III

div.head: Introduction
div.p: As an important freshwater aquaculture species, the annual production of the gibel carp (Carassius auratus gibelio) has rapidly increased in recent years, and it has become one of the most popularly cultured fish in China [1]. Currently, the production capacity of gibel carp exceeds 3 million tons [2]. Paralleling the growth of gibel carp farming, there has been an expansion in aquafeed production, which constitutes 50-60% of the total cost in aquaculture [3][4][5]. Fish meal is a major protein source of commercially cultured fish because of its unique advantages [5]. However, the huge price hike and fluctuating quality of the fish meal, and its uncertain availability due to the declination of https://doi.org/10.1016/j.fsi.2020.04.051 Received 9 January 2020; Received in revised form 22 March 2020; Accepted 23 April 2020 fisheries resources in the last decade [6,7], it is necessary to identify alternative protein sources for fish culture. For sustainable aquaculture, cheap plant proteins have been commonly used to replace fish meal in fish diet [6,8].

The plant protein source is readily available, eco-friendly and environmentally sustainable [9]. Several studies reported the use of different plants as a partial or complete replacement of fishmeal in aquafeeds [6,10,11]. The use of unconventional proteins from plant products, such as seeds, leaves and other agricultural byproducts, can reduce the cost of fish meal [12][13][14][15][16]. However, limited information is available on the utilization of foliage as an alternative or additional protein source as fish feed (e.g. mulberry leaf) [10,17].

Moringa (Moringa oleifera Lam.) is commonly known as a fastgrowing plant species, which is widely available in the tropical and subtropical regions with the great economic importance for the food and medical industry [7,18]. Moringa leaves (MLs) possess medicinal properties, such as anti-inflammatory [19], anti-oxidant [20], hepatoprotective [21] and antibacterial effects [22]. Interestingly, every part of the moringa plant, including leaf, root, bark, seed, flower and pod is edible and contains the compounds that are important for human and livestock welfare [18,23]. It has been reported that the crude protein (CP) content of the leaves is about 260 g kg −1 of which about 87% is true protein [24,25]. A comparison between the amino acid composition of raw and extracted moringa leaves and soybean revealed an identical pattern of the essential amino acids [25,26].

The MLs are the most utilized part of the plant, which contain several bioactive compounds, including ascorbic acid, γ/α-tocopherol, carotenoids, flavonoid constituents (quercetin, kaempferol glucosides and glucoside malonates), crypto-chlorogenic acid, isoquercetin, astragalin, glucosinolates, isothiocyanates and minerals (Ca, K, Fe, etc.) [27]. However, due to the presence of antinutritional factors, the inclusion of a high level of plant proteins in fish diets has resulted in poor feed efficiency and reduced growth [25,28]. It was reported that the replacement of fish meal in a diet for tilapia with MLs beyond a 10% level of total dietary protein replacement, led to poor growth and decreased the nutrient utilization, which could be attributed to the presence of antinutritional factors (ANFs) in MLs [7].

Our previous study has demonstrated that many biochemical changes occurred during fermentation, leading to a reduction of antinutritive factor and improvement of bioactivity and digestibility [29]. MLs contain a small number of tannins, phytates and oxalates [24,30]. However, it contains a high level of non-hemolytic saponins (5.0%), which is lower than other legumes, such as soya bean meal [24,31]. Fermentation is a simple method and an effective tool to remove ANFs from the plant products, which interferes in several physiological functions and results in poor growth of fish [11,32]. Here, we used fermented MLs (FMLs) as feed to replace fish meal in the diet of gibel carp to remove ANFs from MLs.

Gibel carp (C. auratus gibelio CAS III) is an economically important freshwater cultured fish in China. The main objective of this study was to evaluate the effects of dietary replacement of FMLs on growth performance, nutritional and utilization parameters, carcass composition, serum biochemistry, digestive enzyme, antioxidant capacity and immune response and fish resistance against Aeromonas hydrophila infection.

div.head: Preparation and the main composition analysis of FMLs
Preparations of FMLs
div.p: MLs used in this study were harvested from Baoshan city, Yunnan province, China during August to September 2017. A nature drying process was performed in the native sunning ground. The dried leaves were ground in an electric grinder and passed through a 2.0 mm sieve. The leaf meal had a water content of 9.82 ± 0.03% and was stored at room temperature. They were divided into two lots after autoclave sterilization. One lot was untreated (without fermentation), and the other lot was fermented using Aspergillus niger. A. niger is a mycelial fungal species and accepted as a direct-fed microorganism for feed production in some countries, especially China and the USA. It is selected in our study because it is more suitable for the fermentation of leaf material than bacteria due to its higher levels of lignocellulase secretion [33,34]. The fermentation of MLs was done according to our previous study [29].

div.head: Determination of the main compositions of MLs and FMLs
div.p: The main compositions of MLs and FMLs, including crude protein (CP), ether extract (EE), crude fiber, total flavonoids, total phenolic contents, total polysaccharides, total tannins, phytic acid total saponin content were analyzed. The determination methods were used according to our previous studies [29,34]. Each sample was analyzed in duplicates. The changes of the ingredients before and after the fermentation were shown in Table 1. Repetitive examination showed that the proportion of components in MLs was constant.

div.head: Diet preparation
div.p: FML powder was added at the levels of 0 g, 5.0 g, 10.0 g and 15.0 g per 100 g diet, which replaced 0%, 20%, 40% and 60% of fish meal, respectively, on a dry matter basis. Four isonitrogenous (33% crude protein) and isoenergetic (20.2 MJ kg −1 ) diets were formulated, and their chemical composition was presented in Table 2. The four groups were designated as the control, F20, F40 and F60, respectively. All dietary dry ingredients were ground, passed through a 250 μm sieve, and thoroughly mixed, then added to lipid sources and manually mixed to homogeneity. Appropriate water was added and mixed for min. The feed was extruded into pellets of (2.5 mm diameter) by a laboratory granulator (SLP-45, Fishery Mechanical Facility Research Institute, Shanghai, China), air-dried in the ventilation room for 24 h, subsequently sieved through 16 mesh sifter removing broken particle, and stored at −20°C in sealed plastic bags for further studies.

div.head: Experimental fish and feeding trial
div.p: A total of 800 juvenile gibel carp were purchased from a local specialized aquatic fry farm (Gaochun district, Nanjing, Jiangsu province, China). Before the experiment, the fish were acclimatized for two weeks in the laboratory conditions. During the acclimation period, the fish were manually fed with basal diet to apparent satiety twice a day at 9:00 and 16:00. About 33% of the tank water was exchanged once a day before the first feeding.

Fish were fasted for a day before the beginning of the feeding trial. 480 healthy fish (without visual injury or signs of disease) of similar size with an initial body weight of 19.36 ± 0.03 g, were selected and distributed randomly into sixteen 200 L fiberglass tanks (30 fish per tank) in quadruplicate. Each tank of the recirculating rearing system was equipped with continuously aerated and dechlorinated tap water. Fish were fed twice on a daily basis at 9:00 and 16:00 till satiation for 50 days. Uneaten feed was taken out by siphoning after 45 min of feeding and dried to record feed intake. Freshwater was filtered through coral sand and biochemical cotton. Sufficient oxygen was provided by a lower pressure blower continually.

Laboratory conditions (dissolved oxygen: 6.58 ± 0.05 mg/L; pH: 7.3 ± 0.28; ammonia: ≤ 0.3 mg/L; nitrites: ≤ 0.06 mg/L) were kept consistent throughout the experimental period. Water temperature was adjusted to 26 ± 2°C and a natural photoperiod was used during the trial. Animal care and the experiments were conducted according to the Regulations for the Administration of Affairs Concerning Experimental Animals (Ministry of Science and Technology, China) and approved by the Animal Care and Use Committee of Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjing, China.

div.head: Growth performance and feed utilization
div.p: Approximately 24 h after the last feeding, all fish were rapidly netted and weighed to calculate the weight gain rate (WGR), the specific growth rate (SGR), feed intake (FI), feed efficiency (FE), protein efficiency ratio (PER) and the survival rate (SR) using the following equations:

FI (g/day/individual fish): (total dry feed intake)/ (days × the number of fish) FE (%) = 100 × (total final body weight -total initial body weight)/ total dry feed intake PRE (%) = (final body protein -initial body protein)/total protein intake × 100 100 SR (%) = 100 × (final number of fish) / (initial number of fish)

div.head: Sampling and chemical analysis
div.p: After trial, the number of fish was counted and then the body weight of each fish was measured. Three fish per tank were randomly selected and anesthetized using 50 mg/L MS-222 (tricaine methane sulfonate, Argent Chemical Laboratories Inc., Redmond, WA, USA) on ice. Then, blood samples were rapidly collected using heparinized syringes from caudal blood vessels of the fish. After that, the fish were dissected and the weight of isolated hepatic tissues were determined for hepatosomatic index (HSI). The blood samples were centrifuged at 3000 g (4°C, 15 min) and plasma was separated (200 μL) and were stored at −20°C for further analysis. The proximate composition of the whole body of gibel carp, including moisture, crude protein, crude lipid, and ash, were determined according to the methods of AOAC [81].

div.head: Biochemical analysis
div.p: The activities of alanine aminotransferase (ALT), aspartate aminotransferase (AST) in plasma and the contents of total protein (TP) and albumin (ALB) were determined using a BioTek Synergy2 (BioTek Instruments Co., Ltd., American) according to manufacturer's instructions from the Institute of Biological Engineering of Nanjing Jiancheng (Nanjing, China).

div.head: Immunological and antioxidants analysis in serum
div.p: The activities of serum lysozyme (LZM), alkaline phosphatase (AKP), superoxide dismutase (SOD), catalase (CAT) and glutathione peroxidase (GPx), the content of complement 3 (C3), immunoglobulin M (IgM), protein carbonyl content (PCC) and malonaldehyde (MDA) were tested using commercial kits according to the manufacturer instructions (Nanjing Jiancheng Bioengineering Institute, Nanjing, China). RNA isolation and real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) were performed as reported previously [29]. Briefly, total RNA was extracted from snap-frozen tissues using Trizol reagent (Invitrogen) according to the manufacturer's instructions. The RNA quality (ribosomal RNA 28s/ 18s) was evaluated by agarose gel electrophoresis, and RNA concentrations were quantified using a spectrophotometer (NanoDrop 2000, Thermo Fisher Scientific). RNA was reverse-transcribed to complementary DNA (cDNA) using a commercial kit (Takara, Dalian, China). The first-strand cDNA was used as a template for real-time PCR and stored at −20°C. Oligonucleotide primers were designed, synthesized, and standardized for PCR ( Table 3). The mRNA expression levels of toll-like receptor 2 (TLR2), interleukin -1β (IL-1β), IL-8 and tumor necrosis factor-α (TNF-α) in spleen of gibel carp were measured in triplicates using TaqMan real-time PCR system (ABI 7500FAST Sequence Detection System, Applied Biosystems, Carlsbad, CA, USA) with specific TaqMan primers/probes (Applied Biosystems). PCR amplification was performed under standard conditions. The transcript amount was calculated as 2 −ΔCT . Following normalization with respect to βactin expression, transcript fold induction was calculated using the −ΔΔCT method with the quantity of the control group scaled to 1 [29]. β-actin was selected as the reference gene.

div.head: Challenge test and calculation of the relative percent survival (RPS)
div.p: A. hydrophila was purchased from Shanghai Ocean University, Shanghai, China, which was isolated from gibel carp. A. hydrophila was cultured in brain heart infusion (BHI) agar plate, and then isolated and cultured in BHI broth at 30°C for 6 h to log phase. The culture fluid was harvested by centrifugation at 8000 rpm for 10 min at 4°C. Then, the supernatant was removed and sedimentary bacteria was diluted into different concentrations (10 5 -10 9 cfu/mL) with a 0.9% NaCl solution for measuring 7-day LC (the dose of A. hydrophila could kill 50% of the gibel carp) determination. Finally, the 7-day LD 50 for A. hydrophila was identified as 1.2 × 10 7 cfu/mL, which was used for the challenge test.

After 50 days of feeding, the fish from the four groups (4 tanks/ group, 20 fish/tank) were randomly selected and raised in tanks. After five days of acclimatization period, all fish were injected 250 μL of 1.2 × 10 7 cfu/mL bacterial suspension intraperitoneally. 12-h after challenge, 3 alive fish per tank were randomly anesthetized with MS222 and sampled for spleen tissues, which were stored at -80°C. Daily mortality was recorded (the sampled fish were excluded) from 1 to 8 days. The survival rate was calculated as follows: Survival rate (%) = (Number of fish survived/initial number of fish) × 100. The relative percentage survival (%) (RPS) was calculated as the method of Amend [35]: RPS = 1 − [(Mortality (%) in treated group) / (Mortality (%) in control group)] × 100.

div.head: Statistical analysis
div.p: All data were statistically analyzed using SPSS 18.0 software (SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL, USA) and subjected to one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) analysis. Duncan's multiple range test was used to detect the significance of the difference of mean values among different treatments. Significant differences (P < 0.05) between values obtained pre and 12 h post challenge are marked by asterisks above histogram bars Independent-Samples t-tests. Values in the tables were means and pooled SEM. The significant difference level was set at P < 0.05.

div.head: Growth performance and nutrient efficiency
div.p: The growth performance of juvenile gibel carp fed with diets containing different levels of FMLs was presented in Table 4. After 50 days of feeding trial, the growth performance of the fish was significantly reduced by FML substitution of fish meal at 60% level, resulting in reduced FBW (P < 0.05), WGR (P < 0.01), SGR (P < 0.05) and FE (P < 0.05) compared with other groups. The highest FBW, WGR, SGR and FE were observed in F20 and F40 groups, which were statistically similar to the control and significantly higher than F60 group. SR of the three FMLs groups was significantly increased (P < 0.05) compared with the control group. FI and PRE of gibel carp showed no significant difference among the four groups.

div.head: Proximate carcass composition
div.p: The whole body composition of fish at the end of the experiment are given in Table 5. By increasing the inclusion level of FMLs in diets, body moisture increased, while, lipid values decreased significantly (P < 0.05). The crude protein and crude ash content were unchanged in all experimental groups.

div.head: Serum biochemistry
div.p: The results of the serum biochemistry from fish are shown in Table 6. The activities of serum AKP were increased in F40 and F60 groups compared to the control group (P < 0.05). Lower ALT and AST activities were observed in F40 and F60 groups compared to the control group (P < 0.05). The HSI was also significantly decreased (P < 0.05) in F60 group compared with the control and F20 groups.

div.head: Immunological and antioxidant related parameters
div.p: The serum immunological and antioxidant related parameters of gibel carp were shown in Fig. 1 -Fig. 3.

div.head: Antioxidant related parameters in serum
div.p: The results showed that the fish fed FMLs significantly increased the Table 3 Oligonucleotide sequences for reverse transcription and RT-PCR. activities of serum SOD and CAT (P < 0.05) (Fig. 1). The activity of serum Gpx was significantly increased in F40 and F60 groups compared to the control group (P < 0.05). While fish from the three FMLs groups showed lower serum MDA (P < 0.01) and PCC (P < 0.05) contents than those from the control group.

div.head: Immunological related parameters in serum
div.p: As shown in Fig. 2, F20 and F40 groups showed higher activities of serum LZM (P < 0.01) and higher levels of serum C3 (P < 0.01) and IgM (P < 0.01). Meanwhile, the activities of LZM, and contents of C3 and IgM in the F60 group were higher than those in the control group (P < 0.05). Fig. 3 represents the effects of the transcriptional levels of immunerelated genes in spleen of gibel carp fed with FMLs administrated diets at 12 h of post-challenge with A. hydrophila. After 12 h bacterial challenge, immune-related gene expression (TLR2, IL-1β, IL-8 and TNF-α) were significantly up-regulated in spleen of infected fish compared with that of the pre-challenged fish (P < 0.05). However, the increase of IL-8 and TNF-α expressions induced by bacterial challenge in the three FMLs groups was not as high as that of challenged fish in the control group. Fish in FMLs groups after bacterial challenge had lower (P < 0.05) expression levels of IL-8 and TNF-α than the control group. Furthermore, dietary F40 and F60 groups also exerted a preventive effect (P < 0.05) on the increased levels of TLR2 and IL-1β in the spleen of post-challenge.

div.head: Immune related genes expression in spleen
Cumulative survival rate of challenged gibel carp
div.p: The trend of cumulative survival rate of gibel carp after challenged with A. hydrophila was shown in Fig. 4. During the 96-h challenge trial against A. hydrophila, the gibel carp fed with FMLs-supplemented diets displayed significantly less susceptibility to A. hydrophila than that in the control group. Based on the survival rates, the RPS of F40, F60 and F20 vs. the control group was 48.72%, 43.59% and 28.21%, respectively. Meanwhile, F40 and F60 groups showed higher (P < 0.05) RPS compared with F20 group.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: Fermentation is a useful method for producing biological products with health-promoting properties. Dei et al. [36] and Miyake et al. [37] found that fermentation not only alters the original bioactivities of the herbs, resulting in new treatment effects, but also enhances the original treatment efficacy of the active ingredients. Fermentation breaks the plant cell walls and releases phenolic compounds, thereby enhancing nutrient availability and antioxidant activity [38]. A. niger produces enzymes, such as hemicellulases, hydrolases, pectinases, lipases, and tannases [39]. Thus, it has been used extensively to improve agricultural by-products through its action on the substrates, such as lignocellulose, non-starch polysaccharides and proteins [35,40] or to structurally modify the antinutritive factors [41].

MLs are rich in flavonoids and polysaccharides, and the concentration of the flavonoids and polysaccharides increased by 11.18% and 17.39%, respectively, after fermentation (Table 1). Flavonoids are a large group of polyphenolic compounds. The studies have shown that the biological effects of flavonoids are mainly contributed by aglycones [42,43]. Flavonoid aglycones are more easily and rapidly absorbed in the intestine after fermentation [44]. The increase of polysaccharides (Table 1) may be due to the decreased carbohydrate content after fermentation [41].

In the present study, FBW, WGR, SGR and FE of fish were significantly improved when the dietary fish meal (the content of fishmeal was 10%) was substituted by FMLs to 40%. The reasons are as follows: firstly, it may be speculated that flavanol glycosides, namely, quercetin and kaempferol, which are predominant in MLs, as well as the alkaloid moringinine may stimulate voluntary feed intake by controlling glucose homeostasis [45]. Quercetin glycosides contain a sugar group at the third position where glucose is the most common sugar, and galactose and rhamnose are other frequently found sugar groups [46]. Similarly, MLs are reported to contain benzyl isothiocyanate that has antibiotic Values in the same row with different letters indicate difference at P < 0.05 (means ± SEM, n = 4). IBW = initial mean body weight; FBW = final mean body weight; WGR = weight gain rate; SGR = specific growth rate; FI = feed intake; FE= feed efficiency; PRE = protein retention efficiency; SR = survival rate. properties [47], which may partly explain the improved growth performance and decreased mortality. Our previous studies documented that plant or herbal components could balance the gut microbial ecosystem, stimulate the secretion of endogenous digestive enzymes and improve the growth performance [48,49]. However, dietary inclusion of 15% FMLs (F60 group) resulted in decreased FBW, WGR, SGR and FE when compared with F20 and F40 groups. The decreased content of the crude lipid in the fish body Values in the same row with different letters indicate difference at P < 0.05 (means ± SEM, n = 8). TP = total protein, ALB = albumin, AKP = alkaline phosphatase, AST = aspartate aminotransferase, ALT = alanine aminotransferase and HSI = hepatosomatic index. induced by dietary MLs supplementation might be responsible for the decreased body weight gain [50]. Dongmeza et al. [25] also found a reduction of the lipid gain in the fish fed different proportions of the moringa methanol extract. In general, the high level of MLs may inhibit dietary lipid utilization. Thus, a high inclusion level of FMLs might inhibit the dietary lipid utilization and reduce the lipid biosynthesis and lead to lower growth performance and nutrient utilization [25]. Cui et al. [51] found that supplementation of MLs increased the content of polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) in the muscle of broilers, thereby activating the process of fatty acid β-oxidation and resulting in lower fat deposition. The lower HSI might be caused by a reduced deposition of fat in the F60 group, which affected the size of the liver obviously.

The reduction of HSI indices may be associated with the increased metabolism of fish due to the enhancement of protein synthesis in the whole body of fish and improved immunity resulted in the consumption of glycogen and lipid of hepatocytes [52]. Previous studies showed that plant flavonoids can decrease the level of stress and improve hepatopancreatic function in rats [53] and sheeps [54]. Aminotransferases, ALT and AST are recognized as a critical indicator in the diagnosis of digestive function and liver damage in fish [55]. AKP is an important regulatory enzyme that widely present in animals and involved in many essential functions of every living organism [56]. In the present study, dietary supplementation of fish meal with FMLs significantly increased serum AKP activity while decreased the levels of serum ALT and AST. The reason may be related to the antioxidant properties of FMLs and their hepatoprotective properties, leading to prevent lipid peroxidation of cell membranes and finally suppress the liver damage [22,57].

Under normal physiological conditions, the fish body makes its own antioxidant defense mechanisms to scavenge surplus oxygen-free radicals. Among these, the antioxidant enzyme defense mainly includes SOD, CAT, and Gpx, which play essential roles in protecting against the deleterious effects of lipid peroxidation [58]. SOD specifically catalyzes the dismutation reaction of superoxide radicals into hydrogen peroxide (H 2 O 2 ) and molecular oxygen (O ), and provides an important defense mechanism against superoxide radical toxicity, while CAT and GPx degrade H 2 O 2 into water and oxygen [59]. Thus, the activities of the antioxidant enzymes reflect the ability to clear reactive oxygen species (ROS) and the severity of cell impairment. Additionally, MDA, one of the most important lipid-oxidation products, is an important indicator of peroxidative tissue injury and PCC is the most established biomarker of protein oxidation [60]. In the present study, increased SOD, CAT and GPx activities, and reduced MDA and PCC contents in serum were observed in fish fed with FMLs supplemented diets. The abundance of phenolic content in Moringa species confers the high antioxidant activity, which stabilizes free radical generated in a cell by donating or accepting the electrons, therefore acts as an antioxidant molecule [21]. Our results are possibly attributed to the presence of vitamin C, carotenoids, tocopherols, flavonoids and other phenolic compounds in M. oleifera [61]. Antioxidant activity in M. oleifera leaves is further enhanced by the presence of glucosinolates, which carries a benzyl-glycoside and enzymatic hydrolyzes to isothiocyanates, thiocyanates or nitriles [46,62].

The antioxidant defense system is associated with health status and the immune system in fish [63]. As the first line of the defense system, the nonspecific immune system is especially important for the disease resistance in fish [64]. Among them, immunoglobulins (Igs), complement system and LZM are important elements in the humoral immune response to protect against pathogens, such as bacteria and viruses [65]. The results in the present study showed that the levels of C3, IgM and LZM were significantly increased in FMLs groups compared with the control group. Similarly, previous studies have well approved the impacts of plant-derived products on improving non-specific immune responses in various fish and shellfish species [66][67][68]. Similarly, the previous study showed that methanolic extracts of M. oleifera stimulated both cellular and humoral immune responses in mice. This could be due to the presence of compounds, such as isothiocyanate and glycoside cyanides [69].

In fish, the immune status is closely associated with inflammation [70]. Inflammation was initiated and regulated by inflammatory cytokines and chemokines [71]. In the present study, the genes in TLR2 signaling pathway and pro-inflammatory cytokines in spleen were assessed. TLR2 can recognize multiple endogenous and exogenous stress signals to mediate inflammatory response [72,73]. The activation of the signal transduction pathway of TLR2-Myd88-NF-kB can trigger a series of cellular genes related to inflammatory and cytotoxic cytokines, including IL-1β, IL-8 and TNF-α to promote tissue damage [74]. Fard et al. [75] reported that the leaf extract decreased pro-inflammatory cytokines production, such as TNF-α, IL-1β, and IL-6 induced by lipopolysaccharides (LPS) in macrophages through the TLR4-NFκB signaling pathway. In our present study, the transcriptional levels of TNF-α1, IL-1β and IL-8 in the spleen after 12 h bacterial challenge were reduced in fish fed with three FMLs supplemented diets. The present results indicate that the immune response and disease resistance of gibel carp are associated with the regulation of the TLR2 signaling pathway and modulation of the cytokine profile by the supplementation of dietary FMLs. Our previous study indicated that, the flavonoids and polysaccharides can modulate the functions of macrophages and hence normalize the expressions of pro-inflammatory cytokines [76]. The increase observed in the ratio of RPS against A. hydrophila can be attributed to the beneficial effects of FMLs on immune function regulation as well as antioxidant capacity. Similar results were obtained by El-Gawad et al. [77], who reported significant increase in antioxidant enzyme activities in Nile tilapia fed with 5% MLs powder. Furthermore, A. hydrophila infection trial showed that all the fish fed with MLs powder survived compared with only 20% of the controls. In line with present finding, previous studies on other medicinal herbs also revealed beneficial effects on immunomodulatory parameters and disease resistance [78][79][80]. Fig. 3. The transcriptional levels of immune-related genes of toll-like receptor 2 (TLR2) (A), interleukin -1β (IL-1β) (B), IL-8 (C) and tumor necrosis factor-α (TNF-α) (D) in the spleen of gibel carp fed with FMLs administrated diets (5%, 10% and 15%) at 12 h post-challenge with A. hydrophila. mRNA expression levels are normalized to the reference gene (β-actin) and fold changes were calculated against the respective control group (control value = 1). Values represent means ± standard deviation (n = 8). Bars with different lower cases are significantly different (P < 0.05).* means remarkable changes between pre and 12 h post bacterial challenge (P < 0.05 or P < 0.01). Fig. 4. The cumulative survival rate of juvenile gibel carp fed diets with fermented moringa leaves after infection with A. hydrophila. The cumulative survival rate of gibel carp was recorded and analyzed. The equation is expressed as survival rate (%) = (final number of fish survivor/initial number of injected fish) × 100.

In conclusion, this study demonstrates that 40% of dietary fish meal replaced by FMLs could improve growth or feed utilization of gibel carp. 20%-60% of dietary fish meal replaced by FMLs could remarkably improve antioxidant capability, immune response and disease resistance of gibel carp against A. hydrophila. Taken together, FMLs meal can be an effective fish meal substitute and 10 g FMLs per 100 g diet is recommended to be added in feed for gibel carp.

figure.head: Fig. 1 .
figure.figDesc: The activities of serum SOD (A), GPx (B) and CAT (C), and contents of MDA (D) and PCC (E) of juvenile gibel carp fed diets with increasing percentage replacement of fish meal with FMLs for 50 days. Values represent means ± standard deviation (n = 8). Bars with different lower cases are significantly different (P < 0.05).

figure.head: Fig. 2 .
figure.figDesc: The activities of serum LZM (A), and contents of IgM (B) and complement C3 (C) of juvenile gibel carp fed diets with increasing percentage replacement of fish meal with FMLs for 50 days. Values represent means ± standard deviation (n = 8). Bars with different lower cases are significantly different (P < 0.05).

div.p: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https:// doi.org/10.1016/j.fsi.2020.04.051.
